title: Excluding Dylan, Lennon and McCartney, who do you think is the greatest songwriter of all time and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is it possible that there is simply no way to answer this question? We have so many extraordinary people to choose from who are brilliant for as many different talents: lyrics, melody, story-telling, feel-good hooks, pathos, humor, commentary, complexity, etc., etc. I probably couldn’t give you a definitive top 5 if my life depended on it. And my answers would probably change daily, and inevitably I’d forget someone the first time, be reminded, and have to change my list again. But as of this moment, here are the people that jump to mind: Cole Porter — for perfect melody and timeless lyrics, filled with wit and heart.Rogers and Hammerstein — because of perfect, lush, fantastical songs that you never forget, and your grandparents never forgot.Smokey Robinson — for merging true soul with pop economy and making it accessible to anyone with ears.Andy Partridge, leader of UK band XTC — for carrying on the Beatles tradition of mixing punk, pop, ancient folk music, pub sing-alongs, and classical music into something greater than the sum of its parts, all with heart and intelligence.Chuck Berry — for making R and B music and country music a single American music and authentic modern folk poetry.Carole King — for capturing the experience of post-war youth in America and beyond, and showing that divisions between class, religion, geography, race only keep us from being in the moment, dancing joyfully, together.Lieber and Stoller — ditto.Stevie Wonder — for exuberant, positive, funky soul that goes straight to the heart.Kate Bush — for creating a genre that only one person has ever been able to master, and telling compelling, complicated stories about strange and wonderful characters in three-minute symphonies, and for pulling from every musical tradition but erasing all the lines between where one begins and another ends. Sort of like Andy Partridge/XTC in that she takes the trajectory begun by the Beatles to places no one thought existed, and probably much farther than XTC. Like Joni Mitchell, below, she demands a close, close listen for full effect.Joni Mitchell — for pushing the boundaries of meter, key, and language, taking it to its emotive essence, rules be damned, in the tradition of the modernists of the early 20th Century. Like them, she broke the rules, but never left chaos or sloppiness. Instead, she created something more complex, more exacting, reaching ruthlessly into the soul and demanding your attention.Simon and Garfunkel — for starting with the earnest, revivalist simplicity of American folk and transforming it into a transcendent, soothing balm of melody and lyrics, yet never pulling an emotional punch. (EDIT: someone commented that technically, Garfunkel didn’t contribute to the writing of these songs. That is true, though I think his harmonies and arrangements are a key aspect of what makes those songs so emotional, at least for now. It’s a wobbler, I think.)Kirsty MacColl — for being the greatest songwriter most people have never heard of, and someone cut down before she could reach her full greatness. I reserve the right to include her in this list because it’s my answer, and you can answer differently :) A woman who started her musical life as the “Queen of the Covers,” and then quickly became what other people called a female Randy Newman (who should probably be on this list somewhere too). I call her the patron saint of brainy women for her lyrics, which is a very rare thing in pop music, but her melodies are equally capable of eliciting the same feeling that she has peeked into your soul and is breaking the hard news to you. Check out Tropical Brainstorm, her last album before she died in a diving accident, or her penultimate album, Titanic Days. Really, who else could write the line, “Who’d have thought I’d have as much fun with an anonymous Dutchman,” and make it swing?That's today’s list. I’ll probably need to keep changing it as I keep thinking of someone else it would be a crime to exclude. Regardless, though, what I see in my list and most everyone else’s is that all our “greatest songwriters” have one thing in common: they take ordinary forms, merge them with other ordinary forms, ignore the established rules, and bring us something utterly new, yet timeless.

After Lennon-McCartney, who even comes close? Who has written more than even 5 fantastic tunes? To qualify as great - and this is just a way of defining greatness - the song must have something going for it that makes it unusually popular for its tunefulness and presentation for at least 20 years, and then a new generation of listeners should also agree that it is outstanding on the same merits. This helps clear out all those songs that a generation gets stoked on, but everyone else “had to be there” to appreciate. Lennon and McCartney (more accurately, the Beatles) pass the intergenerational test with flying colours. And their catalogue’s sheer quality, volume and variety of tunes gives them several dozen memorable songs. They were trying to keep up with Bach’s production, according to McCartney. Once they found out that he wrote a new song for the church choir to sing every Sunday, they thought that was a good pace to try to keep up with! Let It Be, The Long and Winding Road, Across the Universe, Hey Jude, Strawberry Fields Forever, Penny Lane, I am the Walrus, Because, amd The Abbey Road Medley are just a SAMPLE of their more famous songs, and these are just from their later period. Well behind the Beatles - although with more intricate embelishments in his melodies - is Chopin. What a great tunesmith! Maybe he has 10 songs that rank right up there. Richard Rogers sure wrote a lot of hummable tunes. I don’t know all his songs, but at least 4 of the following songs are really excellent tunes and the others are very good: Blue Moon, Climb Every Mountain, Do-Re-Mi, Edelweiss, Favourite Things, Getting to Know You, Happy Talk, Maria, My Funny Valentine, Oh What a Beautiful Morning, Sixteen Going on Seventeen, Some Enchanted Evening, Sound of Music, You Took Advantage of Me, You’ll Never Walk Alone. I left a few out that are also famous, but I don’t find as good. I like Bach, Beethoven and Tchaikovsky, but they didn’t have the same number of big tunes. They sure had some good ones, but I don’t rank them as great tunesmiths.. Tchaikovsky had a few GREAT original tunes - Piano Concerto No. 1 in B-Flat Minor Op. 23 has a better tune than anything ever written by the Beatles, in my opinion - but he also just worked over some folk tunes. There are artists with a handful of really nice tunes, like George Gershwin and Hoagy Carmichael. And there are many many others who have at least 2 or 3 stellar songs. Paul Simon and Carole King, for example. So many others. I don’t think that Brian Wilson has enough really strong tunes, nor Billy Joel, Steven Stills, Jagger/Richards, and the myriad of others that have 2–3 amazing songs. In my opinion - and millions would beg to differ - Dylan didn’t write enough great tunes to rank as a fantastic songwriter. If his songs didn’t have any lyrics, would they be strong enough tunes? There are many great lyrical songs from the 1800s where the tune wasn’t strong enough to keep the song alive. I’m likely forgetting a few.

In my opinion, it’s either Bowie or Ron Mael of Sparks. Bowie was phenomenal in the sense that he would recycle ideas and lyrics to tell what he was going through at the time. I guess you could say he referenced himself. For example, he used the same character, “Major Tom,” from Space Oddity in Ashes to Ashes. In Ashes to Ashes, he explains that Major Tom’s a junkie, referring to the state he was in when he wrote Space Oddity. He also nonchalantly references other things going on in the world, and you can really understand it when you go through his song lyrics one line at a time and actually think about what each line means. All in all, he had awesome, extraordinary concepts that no normal brain could think of. As for Ron Mael, his lyrics are so witty, clever and humorous. Many people think of Sparks as more of a novelty band, with their only big hit being “This Town Ain’t Big Enough for the Both of us.” However, in songs like “Popularity,” the lyrics are written with such a carefree and mindless way, that it adds a comedic effect to the song. For example, a part of the lyrics goes, “We’ll meet the rest of our friends at a place that’s called…I forget what it’s called, but it’s really great.” Another example of this would be in “When I’m With You.” The lyrics express the same sense of carefree-ness when not being able to think of lyrics, but it works so well that I couldn’t imagine it being any other way. “It’s that break in the song when I should say something special…but the pressure is on and I can’t think of nothing special..Not when I’m with you.” Not to mention, some of the songs are based off of obscure ideas, like “Here Comes Bob” is about a guy named Bob who hits people with his car. It’s that super eccentric stuff that I admire so greatly in music.

Prince might not be the best ever, but he certainly has a place in the pantheon. His lyricism and musicianship place him a cut above. Michael Jackson was also a major talent in the field, as well as Stevie Wonder, for similar reasons. I don’t spend a lot of time considering hierarchies of this kind, but I think it is at least very possible that despite any crimes he (probably—no—definitely) committed, Michael Jackson may be the greatest all-around entertainer in history. It doesn’t bother me that Lennon and McCartney are excluded, but excluding Dylan seems a bit much. Oh, and despite the fact that I’m not a fan, Billy Joel is one of the very best. But then there’s Stephen Foster, Cole Porter, and a myriad of others from ages gone by….

That is a subjective answer. All art is subjective. I do not think it is possible to answer definitively. I can suggest Mozart, Bach, Beethoven. I can suggest Billy Joel, Brian Wilson, George Harrison. I can suggest Burt Bacharach and Hal David. What about Rodgers and Hammerstein? What about Cole Porter or Elton John and Bernie Taupin? What about Michael Stipe of REM? What about Joni Mitchell or Dolly Parton? What about Don Henley or Glenn Frey? Who compares to Carole King? So there is not one. Dylan and then Lennon and McCartney are standouts but in the end it is personal taste as well as the ability to realize we need all of these songs to be complete. I love so many songs, from Tchaikovsky, to Beatles to Stephen Sondheim, to Pink Floyd. I wouldn't choose a best but I would choose a favorite. But you did not ask that.

It's George Harrison! Here are my two reasons. When he was with The Beatles, he got only two songs per album since John-Mccartney wrote the majority of songs. There is always this argument that was George equal to John and Paul? Well, it's a bit technical to say, the question should be like did he get similar numbers of songs to write? So if we consider whatever amount of songs he wrote for the band, he still managed wrote three most famous Beatles songs.His solo career gives testimonials how great he was as a songwriter. I find it annoying when a particular artist is hailed as the greatest songwriter, but the majority of the songs he wrote were “love songs.” Seriously is this how one is considered the greatest? George Harrison wrote a wide variety of songs. He wrote spiritual, philosophical, romantic, erotic, satire, humorous, political, psychedelic, revolutionary, social and sad songs. His lyrics were more profound than what John and Paul wrote, who mostly wrote love songs.Is there any artist who has this wide variety of songs like George Harrison?

I’ll throw in a couple I haven’t seen in these answers: David Ackles: Not well known in the States, popular in England in the late 60s, mid 70s. American singer, songwriter, actor. Put out four PERFECT albums. With influences from folk, rock, Brecht-Weill, Rodgers & Hammerstein, etc., most of his songs were about society’s losers - an ex-con finding out his girl has married his best friend (“Down River” which often makes me cry), guy realizing he doesn’t really belong back home anymore (“Sonny, Come Home”), a man who lacks, finds and then loses faith (“His Name Is Andrew”). There are also some tender and deeply lyrical songs of love and hope. He had a unique and brilliant gift. Check him out on YouTube. There’s not much video, just audio, but he’s well worth a listen. Stephen Sondheim: Arguably Broadway’s most brilliant composer. His lyrics are wickedly funny, unbearably poignant, and utterly musical - usually all at the same time. Check out his brilliance in “Into the Woods” (not necessarily the bigscreen version, which had some great stuff cut, but there’s a PBS original-cast version), “Sweeney Todd” (again, not the movie, find the PBS version with people who can really sing) and “Sunday In the Park With George” (PBS) which has the triple treat of wonderful songs and Mandy Patinkin and Bernadette Peters. Google Barbara Cook singing “Losing My Mind,” the best torch song EV ER, or Mandy and Bernadette doing “Move On” at a Sondheim birthday celebration 25 years after they first sang it in “Sunday In the Park.”

It’s Paul Simon. Even if you included Dylan and Lennon-McCartney, it’s Paul Simon. If you consider songwriting to be equal parts words and music, it’s Paul Simon. Simon’s lyrics are amongst the cleverest and most poetic, his music has been amongst the most daring and innovative, and he manages to bring it all together in an appealing, memorable fashion. And he’s worked at a high level throughout his career, if longevity matters. Dylan or Cohen aren’t as musically interesting; McCartney, Billy Joel and Brian Wilson can’t match Simon’s lyrics. Joni Mitchell was adventurous, but she sacrificed any hooks in the process. Sting and Peter Gabriel also pull it all together, but they’re a little bit worse at everything than Paul Simon.

I cant narrow that choice down to just one artist, and I think different genres will obviously appeal to different people, but I can tell you a couple of my favorites. These artists appeal to me for different reasons, but basically I am drawn to songs that truly tell a story, and the best songwriters seem to have a true genius for being able to tell them with a certain understated flair….. yet with each new song they find a way to be unique again. With that being said, my favorites are, in no particular order: Willie Nelson- Kris Kristofferson - Guy Clark - Townes Van Zandt- & Waylon Jennings.

Viewed a horse race, I just think the Beatles are so far ahead of any horse number two. Yet, I just think it is reasonable to suggest Jimmy Webb. Viewed as metaphor, his lyrics are so very poetic. “All the sweet green icing flowing down. Someone left the cake out in the rain. I don't think that I can take it. Cause it took so long to bake it. And I'll never have that recipe again.” “The moon a phantom roseThrough the mountains and the pinesAnd then the darkness fellAnd the moon's a harsh mistressIt's so hard to love her well” harmony… the way it fools the ear, the mind

I’ll take a stab at this by century. 13th Machaut 14th Dufay 15th Josquin DuPres 16th Dowland 17th Monteverdi 18th Bach or Mozart 19th Schubert 20th and 21st I can’t single anyone out, there are so many. The farther back in time you go, the less “folk/popular” music there is, because it was less likely to be written down and preserved as the ‘church’ had most of the literate musicians. There was the ever popular Anonymous who wrote many timeless melodies like Greensleeves. You had the first American professional songwriter in the 19th century in Stephen Foster, who wrote Jeanie With the Light Brown Hair, Camptown races, Old Folks at Home, Swanee River and many more. I’ll say Schubert for the 19th century because 600 songs by the age of 31 is just pretty awesome.

To me, Freddie Mercury and Brian May of Queen have got to be two of the greatest rock songwriters I've ever listened to. For one thing, May wrote my favorite song of all time: Hammer To Fall from The Works album. He also wrote other classics like Fat Bottomed Girls, Save Me, Now I'm Here, Flash, We Will Rock You, and many others! Mercury on the other hand wrote a lot of the more popular songs like Bohemian Rhapsody, Killer Queen, Bicycle Race, Don't Stop Me Now, Crazy Little Thing Called Love, Somebody To Love, Seven Seas of Rhye, We Are The Champions, and others including the ENTIRE B-SIDE of Queen II, which has my favorite song on the LP: The March Of The Black Queen.

Hmmm well, you prob wont like where i go with this, since your taste is lennon and such… but imo, i think im gonna have to go with Steve Harris from Iron Maiden  the dude has some of the best lyrics ive ever heard, he tells stories that suck you in and hold you captive. Great metaphors, rhyme schemes, everything. Plus he writes the awesome music that takes so much talent just to play, let alone write… so many great songs, prob more than anyone in history with like 13 albums, in which 90% of the songs are fantastic….

“Excluding Dylan, Lennon and McCartney, who do you think is the greatest songwriter of all time and why?” My personal favourite songwriters are: Billy Corgan (Smashing Pumpkins)David BowieFreddie Mercury (Queen)Joakim Berg (Kent)Carol van Dijk/Peter Visser (Bettie Serveert)Why are these my favourites? These are simply the artists I listen to the most. I really love their songs. Dylan, McCartney, and Lennon would not be on my list. I don’t know their music very well.

There are so many wonderful song writers. I believe some of the best of our time are Carole Bayer Sager, Burt Bacharach, Marvin Hamlisch, and Michael Jackson. That’s just naming a very short list. The way the music became popular top 40 hits. The meaning of their lyrics. Artist and songwriter collaboration leading to this listeners’ enjoyment!

Maynard James Keenan.Roger Waters+David Gilmour.Bee GeesThom Yorke+Johnny GreenwoodTom PettySimon and GarfunkelKurt CobainEddie VedderEric ClaptonDolly PartonKeith RichardsNeil YoungFrank SinatraJohnny CashTupacI might have missed out many artists but these are some I know and truly admire. Most of the bands and artists mentioned are pre-90s. And bringing you 21st century geniuses. Ben HowardJustin VernonMarcus MumfordJ.ColeTaylor Swift (Just the beginning albums)Gregory Alan IsakovWolf LarsenTwenty One Pilots That's all I can remember right now.

Greatest of all time! Well take out McCartney for a start (note: good for a pop writer but just below Ray Davies) and John who? Dylan ok I can go with that. But you say of all time, so presumably you include songs by Schubert, Irving Berlin, etc… Messiaen, Richard Strauss……

Lou Reed for bucking the trend of writing pretty hippie songs and embracing the urban reality of urban life, alternative lifestyles and for having a viola player in John Cale and a seductress in Nico singing with a really strong Germanic accent some of the most interesting songs in music. The Velvet Underground were responsible for the launch of many other bands such as Jim Morrison of the Doors who saw them early on performing live.

Seems to me that Van Morrison has to at least be in contention for this. The man has created his own distinctive musical/lyrical voice for half a century now, and he should be considered for the highest of honors for the “Astral Weeks” song-cycle alone. So one vote for “the Belfast Cowboy”.

Neil Young. He has perhaps one of the worlds largest amount of written songs on every topic from love, growing old, to the damage of using drugs to name a few. Classics like old man, sugar mountain, and after the gold rush to name but three.

Two come to mind off the top of my head - Neil Young and Russ Ballard. Young due to the poetry and emotion of his lyrics, Ballard for the universality of his lyrics. How many songwriters can claim to span genres so that a member of ABBA (Frida) and a member of KISS (Ace Frehley) have recorded their songs?

What about Woody Guthrie? Pete Seeger? Leadbelly? Not only did they write a lot of songs, their songs are very frequently covered and copied and used as inspiration for thousands who went after (including Dylan, Lennon and McCartney).

Depends on your meaning of “all time.” Many songs have touched people who feel it was written just for them. Genre is another aspect. This is a vague question, because, we haven't quite made it to the end of time, and when we do, I'm fairly certain that I will not be around to give my opinion.

If you mean “all time” you should at least include the first two thirds of the 20th century. That would include Irving Berlin, Jerome Kern, Harold Arlen, Cole Porter, Hoagy Carmichael, the Gershwins, Rogers and Hart, Rogers and Hammerstein and a few others.

Regardless your feelings about country, the greatest songwriter of the 20th century is Dolly Parton. She’s written literally thousands of songs and hit after hit for countless artists, not just herself.
Bowie bowie Bowie no other artist has penned as much diverse songwriting .
I’m surprised there has been no mention of Schubert. After all, he invented the song and wrote 600 of them (and he only lived until age 31).
Its strictly a matter of opinion, but John Prine should be up there on the list. Dylan with a better sense of humour.
I believe it is Pete Seeger who was probably one of the first to sing anti war songs most powerful being “Where have all the flowers gone?”.
Since no one from the Great American Songbook types are mentioned in the responses, I’m giving this sappy question all the attention it deserves..
Smokey Robinson if I have to pick one. why…..because his lyrics were pure, simple and honest just like young love.
Your pet turtle is a greater songwriter than Lennon and McCartney.
Barry Gibb. He wrote so many great songs for the Bee Gees as well as many hits for others.
Richard Rogers & Lorenz Hart (Rogers & Hart) or Jimmy Cliff. Also, Burt Bacharach.
David Bowie. Doesn’t need any explanation why, does it?
Freddie Mercury… and Bohemian Rapsody lyrics should be reason enough,
George Harrison Roy Orbison JIMI HENDRIX
George Gershwin, Cole Porter, Irving Berlin
Neil Peart - Lyricist Alex Lifeson-Geddy Lee Music
Johnny Cash. I can relate to his music
Easily, Jackson Browne.
Johann Sebastian Bach.
Harry Nilsson
Elton John
Eagles Band
Schubert
Prince
